section.title: &name-icinga; Quickstart
section.para: This guide is intended to provide you with simple instructions on how to install &name-icinga; from source (code) and have it monitoring your local machine within 20 minutes.
No advanced installation options are discussed here - just the basics that will work for most of the users who want to get started.

This guide will give you examples for currently three different Linux distributions: &name-fedora;, &name-ubuntu; and &name-opensuse;. Similar distributions may work as well. That should include &name-redhat;, &name-centos;, &name-debian; and &name-sles;.
For instructions on how to install &name-icinga; on &name-freebsd; please read &name-icinga; on &name-freebsd; instead.
Other distributions may inherit from these examples.

para.emphasis: If you are planning to use a database with &name-idoutils; please read &name-icinga; with &name-idoutils; instead!

section.para: If you follow these instructions, here's what you'll end up with:

listitem.para: &name-icinga; and the plugins will be installed underneath &url-icinga-base;
&name-icinga; will be configured to monitor a few aspects of your local system (CPU load, disk usage, etc.)
The &name-icinga; classic web interface will be accessible at http://localhost/icinga/ or http://yourdomain.com/icinga

section.para: During portions of the installation you'll need to have root access to your machine.
Make sure you've installed the following packages on your system before continuing.

At one time or another you may need to use SNMP-based checks so it is a good idea to install the required packages now. Otherwise some plugins are not compiled i.e. not available when you need them and it would require a recompile of the plugins.
You can install these packages by running the following commands (as root or sudo):
section.programlisting: #> yum install httpd gcc glibc glibc-common gd gd-devel #> yum install libjpeg libjpeg-devel libpng libpng-devel #> yum install net-snmp net-snmp-devel
#> apt-get install apache2 build-essential libgd2-xpm-dev #> apt-get install libjpeg62 libjpeg62-dev libpng12 libpng12-dev #> apt-get install snmp libsnmp5-dev

note.para: The numbers <62/12> might differ, depending on your distribution

section.para: Please use yast to install the packages
Become the root user.
Create a new icinga user account and give it a password:
On some distributions you'll need to add the group in a single step:
For sending commands from the classic web interface to &name-icinga;, you'll need to create a new group icinga-cmd. Add the webuser and the &name-icinga;user to this group:
section.programlisting: #> /usr/sbin/groupadd icinga-cmd #> /usr/sbin/usermod -a -G icinga-cmd icinga #> /usr/sbin/usermod -a -G icinga-cmd www-data (or www, wwwrun, apache depending on the distribution)

note.para: Some usermod-versions (e.g. in OpenSuSE 11 and SLES 11, resp.) are lacking the option -a. In this case please omit the option -a.

section.para: Change to your local source directory i.e. /usr/src
Either fetch the current icinga-core snapshot from &name-icinga; GIT #> git clone git://git.icinga.org/icinga-core.git or from the &name-icinga; Website .
Don't forget to download the Nagios Plugins .
Extract the &name-icinga; source code tarball (or change directory to the GIT snapshot)
Run the &name-icinga; configure script. You will get help by using the --help flag.
Compile the &name-icinga; source code. To see available options, only use "make".

Install binaries, init script, sample config files and set permissions on the external command directory. #> make install #> make install-init #> make install-config #> make install-commandmode or shorter #> make fullinstall
Don't start &name-icinga; yet - there's still more that needs to be done...
Sample configuration files have been installed by using #> make install-config into &url-icinga-base;/etc/. You'll need to make just one change before you proceed...

Edit the &url-icinga-base;/etc/objects/contacts.cfg config file with your favourite editor and change the email address associated with the icingaadmin contact definition to the address you'd like to use for receiving alerts.
&name-icinga; ships with the Classic Web Interface ("the CGIs") which can be installed via
If you are interested in the new &name-icinga; Web, please refer to Install &name-icinga; Web Interface.
Install the Icinga Classic web config file in the Apache conf.d directory.

Create an icingaadmin account for logging into the Icinga classic web interface. If you want to change it later, use the same command. Remember the password you assign to this account - you'll need it later.
If you want to change it later or want to add another user, use the following command:

note.para: Depending on your distribution/Apache-version you may have to use htpasswd2 instead.

section.para: Reload/Restart Apache to make the new settings take effect.

para.emphasis: Compile and Install the Nagios Plugins

section.para: Extract the &name-nagios; plugins source code tarball.
Compile and install the plugins by changing install directory to &url-icinga-base;
Add &name-icinga; to the list of system services and have it automatically start when the system boots (make sure you have installed the init script before).
Verify the sample &name-icinga; configuration files.
If there are no errors, start &name-icinga;.

para.emphasis: Login to the Classic Web Interface

section.para: You should now be able to access the &name-icinga; classic web interface at the URL below. You'll be prompted for the username ( icingaadmin) and password you specified earlier.
or

Click on the "Service Detail" navbar link to see details of what's being monitored on your local machine. It will take a few minutes for &name-icinga; to check all the services associated with your machine.
Make sure your system's firewall rules are configured to allow access to the web server if you want to access the &name-icinga; classic interface remotely.
Setting up your mail transfer agent (MTA) like exim, sendmail or postfix to allow &name-icinga; sending notification emails won't be explained here.
Please refer to the &name-nagioswiki; for more resources.
Congratulations! You successfully installed &name-icinga;. Your journey into monitoring has just begun.
You'll no doubt want to monitor more than just your local machine, so check out the chapter on "Getting Started" about "Monitoring ..."
